JudgeA.name: Response Accuracy
JudgeA.definition: Confidence in the factual correctness and logical soundness of the agent's response, considering accuracy of information, calculations, and reasoning.

JudgeA.name: Completeness
JudgeA.definition: Confidence in the thoroughness of the response, assessing whether all aspects of the task requirements are addressed and no critical information is omitted.

JudgeA.name: Relevance
JudgeA.definition: Confidence in the relevance of the response to the specific task prompt, evaluating how well the content aligns with the task requirements and objectives.

JudgeA.name: Clarity and Coherence
JudgeA.definition: Confidence in the clarity and logical flow of the explanation provided, assessing whether the response is easy to understand and follows a coherent structure.

JudgeA.name: Technical Correctness
JudgeA.definition: Confidence in the technical accuracy of the response, particularly for tasks involving complex calculations, algorithms, or system designs, ensuring that all technical details are correct.

JudgeB.name: Technical Precision
JudgeB.definition: Confidence in the mathematical, algorithmic, and technical accuracy of specific claims and solutions, including correctness of formulas, code logic, and system specifications.

JudgeB.name: Solution Completeness
JudgeB.definition: Confidence that the response addresses all aspects of the task requirements and constraints, with appropriate depth for each component and consideration of edge cases.

JudgeB.name: Reasoning Clarity
JudgeB.definition: Confidence in how well the response explains its approach, assumptions, and trade-offs, with clear logical flow and appropriate justification of key decisions.

JudgeB.name: Implementation Feasibility
JudgeB.definition: Confidence in the practicality and viability of the proposed solution, considering real-world constraints, scalability issues, and technical limitations.

JudgeB.name: Error Handling
JudgeB.definition: Confidence in how thoroughly the response addresses potential failure modes, edge cases, and error conditions, including appropriate mitigation strategies.

JudgeC.name: Response Accuracy
JudgeC.definition: Confidence in the factual correctness and logical soundness of the agent's response, considering accuracy of information, calculations, and reasoning.

JudgeC.name: Completeness
JudgeC.definition: Confidence that the response addresses all aspects of the prompt's requirements, including all sub-tasks and considerations.  A higher confidence indicates a more thorough and comprehensive answer.

JudgeC.name: Relevance
JudgeC.definition: Confidence that the response directly addresses the prompt's core question(s) and avoids irrelevant information or tangents.  Higher confidence indicates a more focused and pertinent answer.

JudgeC.name: Clarity & Coherence
JudgeC.definition: Confidence in the clarity, organization, and logical flow of the response.  A higher confidence score reflects a well-structured and easily understandable explanation.

JudgeC.name: Technical Correctness
JudgeC.definition: Confidence in the correctness of any code, algorithms, or technical details presented in the response.  This includes syntax, logic, and adherence to best practices.
